prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Factors militating against transfer—The motion for transfer is made for an improper purpose

para.paratext: Although not set forth in the statute, and rarely specifically articulated by the Panel, this factor is broad in potential application. The Panel has noted, in a decision denying transfer of similar and probably related tag-along cases, that the “plaintiffs seem determined to use Section 1407 as a means of further delaying a final resolution of their claims against Fairchild.”[1] Although not specifically denying transfer on the grounds that the motion does not pass the “smell test,” the Panel was clearly influenced by its perception of the plaintiffs' procedural ploy.
In another case the Panel denied transfer on a number of conventional grounds, including the fact that only two actions were pending.[2] The Panel went on, however, and stated:

There is an additional and equally compelling reason for denying the requested transfer. In our view, plaintiff's request for transfer is not motivated by a desire to achieve the purposes for which Section 1407 was designed, but rather, by a desire to circumvent obstacles of personal jurisdiction which necessitated here institution of two separate actions. Although the propriety of in personam jurisdiction in a proposed transferee district is not a criterion in considering transfer of actions to that district under Section 1407, it appears that in this particular litigation plaintiff's ulterior motive for seeking transfer amounts to an attempted misuse of the statute.[3]

An analogous situation to consideration of a trial judge's decision on 1404(a) transfer arises when the trial court either certifies or refuses to certify a class action. In one instance the Panel considered a docket of cases arising from the decertification of a nationwide FLSA collective action. That action had been pending since 2004, and that Panel found that although the decertication decision did not dictate a decision by the Panel, the language was compelling and militated against centralization.[4]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
In re Air Crash Disaster Near Silver Plume, Colo., on Oct. 2, 1970, 368 F. Supp. 810, 811 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
In re Highway Acc. Near Rockville, Connecticut, on December 30, 1972, 388 F. Supp. 574 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
